Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Probing the Two Distinct Twin-Arginine Translocases of Acinetobacter baylyi

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Bacteria have the amazing ability to colonize and thrive in diverse environments. Within these diverse environments, the most successful bacteria can adapt to changing conditions and thereby outcompete their microbial neighbors. For soil-dwelling bacteria like Acinetobacter baylyi, one key survival strategy relies on exporting a diverse repertoire of proteins allowing nutrient uptake and resistance to toxic compounds. The long-term goal of this project is to clarify how specific pathways contribute to exporting proteins of A. baylyi, particularly as it relates to aiding survival of this microbe in the wild. This project will provide opportunities for undergraduate and masters students at Hofstra University to gain significant hands-on experience in various areas of molecular microbiology. Integrating part of this research project into existing courses will enhance the educational experience of Hofstra students beyond that obtained in a typical classroom setting. Additionally, students from nearby Brentwood High School will participate in the project thereby introducing them to hypothesis-driven research.

Protein export pathways are found in all cellular organisms, and these pathways are critical for sustaining life. The Twin-Arginine Translocase (Tat) pathway is widely distributed as homologs of it are found in bacteria, archaea, and plant thylakoids. Therefore, understanding how the Tat pathway functions at a molecular level has applications for both eukaryotic and prokaryotic organisms. A. baylyi provides a unique system in which to study Tat-mediated protein export. Indeed, the existence of dual Tat pathways in A. baylyi indicates that Tat-mediated protein export is more complicated than current models suggest. Using A. baylyi as a model to study Tat-dependent protein export will provide insights not available in other model organisms like Escherichia coli. In particular, the researchers will investigate phenotypes important for growth including biofilm formation and cell envelope biogenesis that are dependent on Tat. To identify all Tat substrates in A. baylyi, the investigators will use both a candidate-based approach and a comprehensive proteomic analysis. Lastly, using both genetic and biochemical approaches, they will investigate the molecular architecture of Tat complexes purified from A. baylyi cells.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For proteins to escape the cytoplasm of Gram-negative bacteria, they make use of multi-subunit protein machines that span the inner membrane (IM). The Sec pathway exports only those proteins that remain in an unfolded conformation, while the Tat pathway exports proteins that fully fold in the cytoplasm. To distinguish one transport machine from the other, proteins destined for export have specific signal sequences of amino acids at their N-terminus. Proteins routed to the Tat pathway contain a twin arginine dipeptide in their signal sequence while proteins routed to the Sec pathway lack this sequence motif. The major scientific goal of this research project was to characterize how the dual Twin-Arginine Translocase (Tat) pathways function in supporting growth of Acinetobacter baylyi under different environmental conditions.  The major educational goal of this project was to engage and train scientists of diverse backgrounds and skill levels in a wide variety of molecular microbiology techniques. Regarding our scientific goals, we published three published manuscripts describing our work characterizing various aspects of the Tat pathways of Acinetobacter.  We are drafting two more manuscripts: one that describes the genetic screen we have been pursuing using a novel dominant-negative tat allele to probe Tat complex protein-protein interactions, and another focused on PhoD, the sole Tat2-dependent substrate.

Regarding our educational goals, Dr. Rigel has mentored aspiring scientists at multiple levels during the course of this project.  Since joining Hofstra in 2013 and beginning this project in 2016, Dr. Rigel has trained/is training a total of 2 research technicians, 4 graduate (masters) students, 34 undergraduate students, and 19 high school students.  Many of these students have gone on to present their work at regional and national conferences and competitions.  Of note, one graduate student was awarded the NSF Graduate Research fellowship, a first at Hofstra.  Two high school students from Central Islip have been first-round winners of the annual Regeneron Science Talent Search.

While all bacteria possess the Sec pathway, only some bacteria use the Tat pathway. Tat substrates serve a broad array of functions including nutrient acquisition, cell wall maintenance, and virulence. Acinetobacter baylyi is unique in that it encodes not one, but two distinct Tat machines. Studies performed by my lab and others showed that one of these translocases (TatA1B1C1) is essential for growth, while the other (TatA2B2C2) is not. A. baylyi is the first known example of a bacterium with both essential and non-essential Tat pathways. Using bioinformatics, we have identified a list of candidate Tat substrates and are currently testing these predictions in vivo. We have identified PhoD as being exclusively dependent on TatA2B2C2 for export. We have constructed loss-of-function mutations in the tatA2, tatB2, and tatC2 genes and have discovered that without the non-essential Tat machine, A. baylyi has defects in cell wall biogenesis that interfere with growth. We have also shown that the non-essential Tat pathway is important for growth of A. baylyi when cultured in competition with other bacterial species. Using a classic genetic approach called suppressor analysis, we probed the interactions between the members of the Tat complex. We believe that our studies of the architecture and substrate specificity of the dual Tat machines of A. baylyi will provide novel insights into how these machines operate in all bacteria.
